title.narrative: Renforcer les capacités et les mécanismes de prévention et de reponse en cas de catastrophe dans les camps de réfugiés sahraouis Tindouf (Algérie).

description.narrative: Ce projet vise à développer et à renforcer les capacités, ainsi que les mécanismes de prévention et de réponse des institutions,des organismes et de la communauté de réfugiés sahraouis face aux catastrophes dans les camps.Les pertes humaines et matérielles durant ces dernières années dans les camps de réfugiés sahraouis ont mis en évidence la fragilité des mécanismes existants pour prévenir et répondre aux éventuels risques causés par les catastrophes naturelles,tel que les inondations,vents violents et bien dautres risques qui frappent la région,c'est pourquoi il est necessaire de mettre en place dun plan visant à réduire au minimum les effets déventuelles catastrophes.En même temps que la prévention et la préparation,un mécanisme de réponse sera mis en place pour la protection des membres affectés par les dégâts.Afin datteindre cet objectif,on propose de travailler sur plusieurs axes d'intervention.Le premier;consiste à renforcer la capacité des institutions à la préparation,en donnant une formation adéquate,accompagnée dun soutien technique pour l'élaboration des plans de gestion des risques,des catastrophes et des plans de contingence (en tenant compte des mesures spécifiques pour les groupes plus vulnérables).Ensuite,renforcer la coopération et la coordination entre institutions et organisations concernées.Les organismes du gouvernement,services de la protection civile algérienne et d'autres organisations présents dans la région seront également intégrés dans ce plan.De même,une campagne de sensibilisation sera lancée,pour que la population puisse se préparer face aux désastres.Enfin,adapter des mesures de préparation et mitigation telle que définies dans les plans de GRC et mettre à disposition un certain nombre de matériels et déquipements,pour donner une réponse rapide et appropriée.L'exécution du projet sera dirigée par le Croissant-Rouge Sahraoui soutenu par la CRE.

title.narrative: Strengthening the Sahrawi Education system through improving WASH in school services and developing capacity of teachers and trainers

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters

The Sahrawi refugee situation in Tindouf (South Western Algeria) is in its 44rd year and remains one of the most protracted refugee crises in the world. Some 173,600 in 2017, refugees, recognized as prima facie by the Algerian Government, live in five camps in a state of complete dependence on humanitarian assistance and with the virtual hope of a sustainable political solution through a referendum to be negotiated with Morocco and organized by the MINURSO. Opportunities to engage in economic activities are limited due to harsh environmental conditions and remote location of the camps. Child and maternal mortality rates are higher than their levels in other countries of North Africa, anemia is widespread because of the limited access to fresh food; in addition, adequate infrastructures for basic education are often lacking and the quality of education requires reinforcement. Due to the protracted nature of the crisis, the refugee program has also suffered from declining funds in recent years. In October 2015, August 2016 and July 2017, heavy rains and windstorms hit the region severely damaging shelters, health infrastructures and particularly endangering access to schools for thousands of children. Despite solidarity shown by the international community, Sahrawi refugees are in a tricky situation resulting from diminishing funds for humanitarian assistance. This projected Action by UNICEF seeks to reinforce the quality of the education sector, improve the learning environment for over 40,000 children and support the development of skills for education personnel, managers and teachers. The proposed Action is the continuation of previous Action carried out in 2017 and 2018 allowing to rehabilitate some education facilities, improve WaSH in Schools and initiate a capacity development program for teachers and education managers.

title.narrative: APPUI AU DEPLOIEMENT D'UN SYSTEME OPERATIONNEL, TRANSSECTORIEL ET INTEGRE, DE REDUCTION DES RISQUES DE CATASTROPHE (RRC) AU NIVEAU MUNICIPAL.

description.narrative: Le cadre d'action national de RRC de 1991, désormais dépassé, doit faire face à des revendications sociétales de plus en plus marquées au sein de la jeune démocratie tunisienne. Le cadre législatif et réglementaire mériterait d'être rénové et consolidé dans le cadre d'une future stratégie nationale qui reste à élaborer dans un contexte interministériel, en liaison étroite avec la société civile et les populations locales.La Constitution de 2014 prévoit un transfert de compétences de l'Etat vers les collectivités locales constituées d'élus. Les 1eres élections municipales se sont déroulées en mai 2018. Ce dernier impactera nécessairement la gestion des risques localement mais avec une capacité réduite d'action faute d'organisation et de compétences au niveau des municipalités. La coordination de l'action des différents échelons territoriaux élus et de l'Etat sera un enjeu majeur dans un principe affirmé de subsidiarité et d'interopérabilité.La proposition consiste à appuyer le déploiement de systèmes municipaux, en liaison étroite avec les gouvernorats et l'échelon national institutionnel, de réduction des risques de catastrophe sur les territoires des municipalités de Boussalem et de Tataouine. Ces systèmes reposent sur la mise en place de solutions techniques de prévention des risques mais également de réponse opérationnelle en cas d'aléa par la protection et la sauvegarde des enjeux humains et de patrimoine. Cette réponse opérationnelle doit pouvoir être anticipée en s'appuyant sur une procédure de vigilance météorologique et un système d'alerte précoce.Cette proposition s'inscrit dans la continuité et la complémentarité de projets réalisés ou en cours (le système opérationnel ne concernera que Boussalem, au vu du projet PNUD engagé à Tataouine) et devrait servir de laboratoire de bonnes pratiques pour une future dissémination dans un cadre légal rénové.

Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (ECHO)

title.narrative: Responding to the trauma casualties and advocating for upholding the International Humanitarian Law in Gaza

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters,Action C: DIPECHO

The funding from DG ECHO will specifically contribute to maintaining and enhancing the pre-hospital management of trauma patients sustained during the demonstrations of the Great March of Return in order to decrease risk of death as well as the physical and mental health consequences amongst injured cases. Secondly, it will ensure access to healthcare for trauma and non-trauma patients admitted in the emergency departments of key Ministry of Health (MoH)-designated trauma hospitals. Thirdly, it will also strengthen the protection of health care.The total number of people that will benefit from the ECHO funding will be 357,295 people, across the Gaza Strip, until December 2020.WHO will support pre-hospital trauma management through enhanced coordination, procurement and distribution of medical supplies and improvement of quality of care for trauma management at the ten TSPs established by the MoH and the PRCS. WHO will also support six MoH Mental Health Emergency Teams in Gaza to provide timely and quality community (MHPSS services for injured people. WHO will also work to improve monitoring of attacks on health care, provision of protection training and equipment to medical staff involved in the pre-hospital management of trauma causalities, and enhanced advocacy at local, regional and international levels.Annex 1 MR9_14.1.20 MR/04/03 May 2020: Due to COVID 19 pandemic WHO reached an agreement with ECHO to reprogram funds remaining under the budget category “Supplies, commodities, materials” to fund activities that scale up the capacity of the health system for testing, case management and IPC in response to COVID19 pandemic MR/05/01 November 2020: following COVID-19 community outbreak WHO reached an agreement with local ECHO Representative to submit an NCE to continue working on the limb reconstruction center in Nasser Hospital-Gaza

title.narrative: Supporting basic education for Syrian refugees and Egyptian host communities in Greater Cairo, Alexandria and Damietta

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters

The action will be extended for six months, allowing the support to extend for the first half of the next academic year. The extension is responding to the adverse impact of COVID-19 on the grant, and the resulting suspension of all project activities since March 2020. The COVID-19 specific response interventions are planned to be held immediately during the original 28 months (starting May 2020) while the additional 6 months starting October 2020 will allow continuation of implementation of the original activities in Syrian learning centres (SLCs) . After the recent MoE decision to cancel al planned activities with teachers and children in public schools for the next academic year 2020-2021, cash grants and light repairs are the only two activities continuing in public schools, and cancelled activities in public schools are replaced with new activities in the SLCs added across the different results. Proposed activities include providing learning centres’ educators with trainings on interactive online learning, child protection and anti-bullying, distributing back-to-school kits to enrolled children in targeted learning centres, shaping peace clubs with children using Games of Human Rights manual, forming parenting circles to tackle various parenting needs , and equipping SLCs more regularly with sterilization and hygiene kits considering COVID-19. Additionally, to mitigate the impacts of COVID-19 on children’s safety and education, this action will also be supporting each SLCs to first develop a Safety protocol to ensure safe return to education of children, teachers and other education personnel and second a Contingency plan that will include actions to be taken by SLCs management committees to ensure continuity of learning in case children’s education will be disrupted by COVID19 outbreak in the centre (more details in section 4 of the ESF).

title.narrative: Reaching Vulnerable Refugee Children from Syria and Palestine, including vulnerable Host Community Children, in Lebanon with Pathways and Opportunities to Quality Education and Protection Services

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters

The activities proposed in this action will run from June 2018-May 2021 and contains a MR for HIP 2020 funds; the MR will allow NRC to extend non-formal education activities with support of the local partner, Amel Association for additional Basic Literacy and Numeracy programming. NRC will maintain outreach capacity and continuously improve referral pathways for children. NRC will continue to produce relevant documentation that will be used for advocacy purposes and to better target our intervention in reaching the most marginalized groups. NRC will implement non-formal education activities as outlined in the Ministry of Education and Higher Education (MEHE) strategy "Reaching All Children with Education". Activities include Community-Based Early Childhood Education for children of pre-school age; and Basic Literacy and Numeracy for out of school children (OOSC).NRC will particularly focus on out-of-school children, facilitating learning pathways and internal or external referral whenever needed, building on continuous coordination with ECHO partners and interventions as well as broader inter-sector coordination, in order to mitigate barriers to education through a multi-sectoral integrated response.NRC up until end 2019 continued to host the Lebanon Humanitarian INGO Forum; LHIF activities have been added as part of the first MR. The aim was to enable continued provision of an independent platform for INGOs in Lebanon to advocate on key issues of common interest, more effectively engage in response coordination and leadership and help ensure humanitarian space is maintained.

title.narrative: Support trauma, secondary and primary health care services for affected populations in Hassakeh, Ar-Raqqa and Deir-ez-zor (North East Syria).

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters

This project proposal aims to address gaps in health services and health supply chain to support life-saving and essential health services provided by INGOs operating in North East Syria The project will be operationalized and coordinated from WHO regional office in Cairo with strong support from the logistics platform at the WHO Iraq office and WoS Coordinator to strengthen health coordination and needs-based distribution and response. The main focus of the proposal is to support health supply chain of required medical kits to strengthen service provision by partners operating in NES, the proposal will also aim to strengthen health coordination and logistic capacity in Iraq.
